regions.crop_image_path: /mnt/sh_flex_storage/home/zehanyu/repos/GPT-Paper/pdfs/cancer_review/HEP 2020 Predicting survival after hepatocellular carcinoma resection using/crops_ordered/page_10/region_1_text.png
regions.text:
CHOWDER and 0.70 for SCHMOWDER (Figure 5A). As for the discovery set, both models
outperformed all the other available features and the CS integrating all relevant baseline
characteristics. The CS indeed gave a mean c-index of 0.63, which represents a 26% increase
with respect to a random prediction, while CHOWDER and SCHMOWDER featured an increase
of 36% (p=3.6e-5) and 40% (p=3.4e-9), respectively. (Figure 5A). SCHMOWDER significantly
outperformed CHOWDER (p=4.5E-2) and was an independent prognostic factor (p=3.2E-7). We
used the threshold established with the discovery set to classify patients into high and low-risk
subclasses. This classification stratified the population of the validation set more effectively than
the CS or any other variable (HR=2.6, p=3.2E-7 and HR=4.3, p=2.5E-12 and HR=3.4, p=5.3E-11
for the CS, CHOWDER and SCHMOWDER,, respectively) (Figure 5B).

regions.crop_image_path: /mnt/sh_flex_storage/home/zehanyu/repos/GPT-Paper/pdfs/cancer_review/HEP 2020 Predicting survival after hepatocellular carcinoma resection using/crops_ordered/page_10/region_2_text.png
regions.text:
SCHMOWDER also predicted survival even after stratification for other common prognostic
features (microvascular invasion, cirrhosis, serum AFP concentration and AJCC tumor stage).
Survival curves for the risk subgroups are provided in Figure 6.

regions.crop_image_path: /mnt/sh_flex_storage/home/zehanyu/repos/GPT-Paper/pdfs/cancer_review/HEP 2020 Predicting survival after hepatocellular carcinoma resection using/crops_ordered/page_10/region_3_title.png
/mnt/sh_flex_storage/home/zehanyu/repos/GPT-Paper/pdfs/cancer_review/HEP 2020 Predicting survival after hepatocellular carcinoma resection using/crops_ordered/page_10/region_4_text.png
regions.text:
The architecture of CHOWDER enables it to retrieve the most predictive tiles from among the
thousands processed. We investigated the main histological determinants of survival, by
extracting the 400 most predictive tiles (high risk of death: 200, low risk of death: 200) from 245
WSlIs with CHOWDER and having them reviewed by a pathologist with expertise in liver disease
and tumors (JC). Nineteen histological features were recorded in tumoral areas, and the features
most predictive of a high risk of death were the presence of vascular spaces (p=1.3E-10), a
macrotrabecular architectural pattern (p=8.6E-5), a high degree of cytological atypia (p=1.4E-8)
and nuclear hyperchomasia (p=1.4E-8). In both tumoral and non-tumoral areas, fibrosis and
immune cells were associated with a low risk score (p=1.1E-3 and 3.4E-8, respectively) (Figure
7). Overall, these results demonstrate that our deep learning model can detect both known and
novel histological patterns associated with survival in HCC patients.

regions.crop_image_path: /mnt/sh_flex_storage/home/zehanyu/repos/GPT-Paper/pdfs/cancer_review/HEP 2020 Predicting survival after hepatocellular carcinoma resection using/crops_ordered/page_10/region_5_text.png
regions.text:
We further performed UMAP on the subsets of low and high risk tiles reviewed, augmented with a
random selection of tiles that cover the whole distribution of predicted risks. Panel B of Figure 7
shows the distribution of tiles from both datasets, using a 2D embedding of the 256-dimensional
autoencoded features. Interestingly, the generated graphs show that tiles tend to cluster
according to their risk class. To further analyze the morphological variations caught by the model,
we also performed a clustering of the data into 8 clusters using K-means algorithm. Among those
clusters, 3 were clearly associated with an increased or reduced risk (clusters 0, 1 and 3 on the
